item.title: Syrians in Hard-Hit Areas of Turkey Rush to Border to Return Home
item.description: In Turkey, officials said that rescue efforts were focused on several hundred buildings where there was a chance of finding any survivors.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times

item.title: Scotland’s Leader Nicola Sturgeon Says She Will Step Down in Surprise Move
item.description: Ms. Sturgeon, a longtime champion of Scottish independence, has been first minister since 2014.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Jane Barlow
item.media:description: Nicola Sturgeon said on Wednesday that she would step down as first minister of Scotland.

item.title: Russian Losses in Battle Suggest Early Struggles for Offensive
item.description: Weeks of failed attacks on the eastern city of Vuhledar have left two Russian brigades in tatters, Ukrainian and Western officials say. Here’s what we’re covering:
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Tyler Hicks/The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers taking cover in a trench as Russian forces fire near their position, in the Donbas region, Ukraine, on Tuesday.

item.title: In Bleak Russian Cemetery, Sea of Crosses Signals War’s True Toll
item.description: A dismal, snowy plot near the Black Sea is the final resting place for more and more soldiers from the Wagner mercenary forces, a testament to the huge casualties Russia is suffering in its invasion.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins and Nanna Heitmann
item.media:credit: Nanna Heitmann for The New York Times
item.media:description: Graves of fallen Russian soldiers from the Wagner mercenary forces on the outskirts of Bakinskaya, a town in Russia, as seen this month.

item.title: In Turkey After the Earthquake, Hope Fades for Waiting Families
item.description: Residents of Adiyaman, hit hard by the quake, hold impromptu vigils while they await news of relatives still under the rubble, feeding wood from shattered cupboards into fires to keep warm.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard, Safak Timur and Emin Ozmen
item.media:credit: Emin Ozmen for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mourning after rescuers found the body of a relative in a collapsed building in Adiyaman, Turkey, on Tuesday.

item.title: As Taliban Settle In, Kabul’s Green Zone Comes Back to Life
item.description: Walking down its streets a year ago was like wandering into the modern ruins of another empire come and gone from Afghanistan. Now, the Taliban have adopted the former diplomatic enclave as their own.
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum
item.media:credit: Kiana Hayeri for The New York Times
item.media:description: Taliban fighters praying in August in Masood Square, just outside Kabul’s Green Zone, and in front of what used to be the American embassy.

item.title: Italy’s Giorgia Meloni Vexes Europe by Playing Nice, Mostly
item.description: Some still fear an authoritarian turn, but Giorgia Meloni has surprised many by showing a pragmatic streak since coming to power. Now Europe is not sure what to do.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:credit: Vincenzo Pinto/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni of Italy at a news conference with NATO’s general secretary in Rome in November.

item.title: U.S. Arrests Four More in the Assassination of Haiti’s President
item.description: The suspects, including three Americans, were arrested and indicted by a federal grand jury on Tuesday for their alleged ties to the 2021 killing.
item.dc:creator: Maria Abi-Habib, Natalie Kitroeff, Frances Robles and Nick Madigan
item.media:credit: Adriana Zehbrauskas for The New York Times
item.media:description: The home in Port-au-Prince where President Jovenel Moïse was assassinated in July 2021.

item.title: Guided Missile Killed U.S. Aid Worker in Ukraine, Video Shows
item.description: A Times analysis suggests that an intentional strike, not an indiscriminate attack, most likely killed Pete Reed. It is unclear whether the attackers knew he was with a group of aid workers.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Malachy Browne
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: Jewels in Camilla’s Crown Will Not Include Famed Diamond Claimed by India
item.description: For the coronation of King Charles III and the queen consort, she will wear a century-old crown that does not include the storied Koh-i-Noor diamond, taken from India under British rule.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
item.media:credit: Pool Photograph/Corbis, via Getty Images
item.media:description: A close-up of the Queen Mother’s coffin, and the Queen Mother’s coronation crown with the priceless Koh-i-Noor diamond, in London in 2002.

item.title: What to Know About Israel’s Planned Judicial Reform
item.description: The government says its plan is a much-needed reform to curb the influence of an overreaching judiciary; critics say it will undermine the country’s democratic institutions.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:credit: Avishag Shaar-Yashuv for The New York Times
item.media:description: A protest against plans by Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s new government to overhaul Israel’s judicial system, on Monday in Jerusalem.

item.title: Greece Border Abuses Highlight Europe’s Clashing Priorities on Migration
item.description: The top rights officer at Europe’s border agency said in a confidential report that it should stop working with Greece because border guards there were mistreating asylum seekers.
item.dc:creator: Monika Pronczuk and Matina Stevis-Gridneff
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.media:credit: Petros Giannakouris/Associated Press
item.media:description: Border guards with the Greek police patrol a barrier between Greece and Turkey in October. Greece has been criticized for forcing people back into Turkey without processing their asylum requests.

item.title: Nigerian Election 2023: What to Know
item.description: The presidential election this month in Africa’s most populous country is completely unpredictable. An unexpected third candidate with a huge youth following may upend decades of traditional politics.
item.dc:creator: Ruth Maclean
item.media:credit: AFP; AFP; AFP; AP
item.media:description: Candidates in the race to become Nigeria’s next president, from left: Bola Ahmed Tinubu, Atiku Abubakar, Peter Obi, Rabiu Kwankwaso.

item.title: Indian Tax Agents Raid BBC Offices After Airing of Documentary Critical of Modi
item.description: The authorities under Prime Minister Narendra Modi have often used such raids in what activists call an effort to silence dissent.
item.dc:creator: Mujib Mashal
item.media:credit: Altaf Qadri/Associated Press
item.media:description: Indian tax agents raided the BBC offices in this building in New Delhi on Tuesday.

item.title: 6,000 Ukrainian Children Are Being Held in Russian Camps, Report Finds
item.description: Children as young as four months old are being held in “integration programs” designed to Russify them, according to researchers.
item.dc:creator: Carly Olson
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: Captain of Thai Soccer Team Who Survived Cave Rescue Dies in England
item.description: Duangpetch Promthep, 17, was a member of the soccer team that made an extraordinary escape from a submerged cave in Thailand in 2018. The cause of his death was unclear.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai and Muktita Suhartono
item.media:credit: Sakchai Lalit/Associated Press
item.media:description: Duangpetch Promthep, one of the boys rescued from the flooded cave in northern Thailand, with relatives after his return home in 2018.

item.title: Who Is Nicola Sturgeon, Scotland’s Longest-Serving First Minister?
item.description: Nicola D
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Nicola Sturgeon, the first minister of Scotland, said she would resign from her position of more than eight years.

item.title: Diversity vs. Fairness
item.description: When the Supreme Court upheld affirmative action in the 1970s, it helped lay the groundwork for the program’s demise.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Jeff Taylor/Associated Press
item.media:description: The Supreme Court on Oct. 12, 1977, before the oral argument in Regents of the University of California v. Bakke.

item.title: Thousands of Syrian Refugees in Turkey Rush to Border Crossing to Return Home
item.description: The Syrian administration of a key border crossing into opposition-held territory in northwestern Syria said that Turkey would allow Syrians to leave the country and then return. Thousands flocked to the border.
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim and Nicole Tung
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Syrians waited to cross back into Syria from Turkey, where many of them lost homes in the earthquake, at the Cilvegozu border crossing on Wednesday.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing
item.description: Rescues in Turkey against the odds.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Ismail Coskun/Ihlas News Agency, via Reuters
item.media:description: Muhammed Enes Yeninar, a 17-year-old earthquake survivor, is rescued from the rubble of a building some 198 hours after last week’s devastating earthquake, in Adiyaman, Turkey, on Tuesday.

item.title: How Climate Change Is Spreading Malaria in Africa
item.description: The mosquitoes that transmit the disease dramatically increased their range over the last century as temperatures warmed, scientists reported.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.media:credit: Soumyabrata Roy/NurPhoto, via Reuters
item.media:description: Mosquitoes that transmit malaria have moved away from the Equator by about three miles per year over the past century, according to a new study.

item.title: NATO Allies Discuss Arms Supply for Ukraine as Battles Loom
item.description: One of Ukraine’s biggest problems in fighting the Russian invasion is a basic one: It is firing artillery rounds much faster than its Western backers are producing them.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger and Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Ukrainian artillery unit in December. The Ukrainian military is expending far more ammunition than can be replaced as it duels with Russia in a large artillery battle along the front.

item.title: After Ohio Derailment and Chemical Spill, Health and Environmental Fears Grow
item.description: Experts say more work could be needed to determine the consequences after a release of toxic chemicals from a Feb. 3 train crash.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong and Catrin Einhorn
item.media:credit: Lucy Schaly/Pittsburgh Post-Gazette, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A worker specializing in hazardous waste abatement works near this month’s disaster in Ohio.

item.title: New Zealand Calls State of Emergency for Cyclone Gabrielle
item.description: The cyclone, which caused severe flooding and cut power to 225,000 residents, was “the most significant weather event New Zealand has seen this century,” Prime Minister Chris Hipkins said.
item.dc:creator: Michael Levenson and Judson Jones
item.media:credit: David Rowland/AAP, via Reuters
item.media:description: Cyclone Gabrielle caused landslides that threatened homes in Auckland, New Zealand.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing: Miracle Rescues in Turkey
item.description: Also, the balloons over the U.S. and India’s raid on the BBC’s offices.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:credit: Ismail Coskun/Ihlas News Agency, via Reuters
item.media:description: Muhammed Enes Yeninar, a 17-year-old earthquake survivor, is rescued from the rubble of a building some 198 hours after last week’s devastating earthquake, in Adiyaman, Turkey, on Tuesday.

item.title: European Union to Ban Gas-Powered Cars by 2035
item.description: The law is part of the E.U.’s ambitious plans to make the 27-member bloc carbon neutral by 2050.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Eddy
item.media:credit: Oliver Berg/Picture Alliance, via Getty Images
item.media:description: The Ford factory in Cologne, Germany. The automaker said it would cut jobs at the plant as it pivoted to electric-vehicle production.

item.title: Earthquake Shows Turkey’s Cities Didn’t Get The Care They Need
item.description: Cities are a form of life and they need constant care to stay strong. They didn’t get that care in Turkey.
item.dc:creator: Michael Kimmelman
item.media:credit: Emin Ozmen for The New York Times
item.media:description: People search for survivors in Kahramanmaras, Turkey.

item.title: Ukraine Urges Civilians Out of Bakhmut as Russia Edges Closer to City
item.description: Fewer than 5,000 residents remain in the eastern city, out of a prewar population of 70,000, as Russian forces close in.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: A resident on the eastern side of Bakhmut, Ukraine, receiving food from a Ukrainian soldier in January.

item.title: Netanyahu’s Judicial Overhaul Plan Divides Even Israel’s Religious Right
item.description: A plan to limit judicial influence set off a rancorous debate, mass protests and even fears of political violence. Now, some among the government’s religious right-wing base are breaking ranks.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:credit: Avishag Shaar-Yashuv for The New York Times
item.media:description: “I want consensus on something as big as this,” said Ariella Dubrowin, holding a sign at right, at a rally in the settlement of Efrat in the occupied West Bank on Saturday.

item.title: Moldova Briefly Closes Airspace After President Accuses Russia of Coup Plot
item.description: The closure, because a presumed air balloon, came days after a Russian missile flew over Moldova’s territory and after the country’s president accused Moscow of trying to sabotage her government.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev and Monika Pronczuk
item.media:credit: Andreea Campeanu for The New York Times
item.media:description: Chisinau, Moldova, in December. The country briefly closed its airspace on Tuesday.

item.title: Amid Turkey Quake Rubble, Gasps of Air and Miraculous Rescues
item.description: Nine people were rescued in Turkey over a week after a 7.8-magnitude earthquake devastated the region. The rescues were rare bright spots in one of the bleakest periods in memory for Turkey.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz and Gulsin Harman
item.media:credit: Ismail Coskun/Ihlas News Agency, via Reuters
item.media:description: Muhammed Enes Yeninar, a 17-year-old earthquake survivor, is rescued from the rubble of a building some 198 hours after last week’s devastating earthquake, in Adiyaman, Turkey, on Tuesday.

item.title: A balloon and 3 U.F.O.s
item.description: What is the U.S. shooting down? Here’s what we know.
item.dc:creator: German Lopez
item.media:credit: Chad Fish/Associated Press
item.media:description: A Chinese balloon and a U.S. fighter jet off the coast of South Carolina on Feb. 4.

item.title: When a Visit to the Museum Becomes an Ethical Dilemma
item.description: Western museums are major tourist attractions, drawing travelers from around the world. But what responsibility do we bear as spectators for patronizing institutions that display what critics say are stolen works?
item.dc:creator: Charly Wilder
item.category: Edo Museum of West African Art
item.media:credit: Andreas Meichsner for The New York Times
item.media:description: A 16th-century Benin Bronze sculpture at the Humboldt Forum, a Berlin museum that has begun to repatriate some of the artifacts to Nigeria. The bronzes were taken from the Kingdom of Benin in 1897 by British forces.

item.title: Isolation and Resignation in Turkish Villages Hit by Earthquake
item.description: In rural southern Turkey, some villages were cut off from aid for days, and locals were left to fend for themselves.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee, Nimet Kirac and Sergey Ponomarev
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Damaged houses in Kayabasi, Turkey, on Monday.

item.title: New Skyscraper, Built to Be an Environmental Marvel, Is Already Dated
item.description: One Vanderbilt, in the heart of New York City, is built to be especially climate friendly. But the design landscape and city rules have changed quickly.
item.dc:creator: Ben Ryder Howe
item.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times
item.media:description: One Vanderbilt, one of the world’s greenest new skyscrapers, stands beside Grand Central in New York City.

item.title: After U.S. Downs UFOs, More Awareness of Balloons All Over Our Skies
item.description: As more unidentified objects were shot down by the U.S. Air Force in recent days, experts warned that there were an “endless” array of potential targets.
item.dc:creator: William J. Broad
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: NASA
item.media:description: NASA scientists in Antarctica prepared one of 20 balloon launches for a scientific mission in 2013.

item.title: The Toll That Twitter’s Glitches Are Taking on Chinese Activists
item.description: As the Elon Musk-owned social media service encounters interruptions and bugs, Chinese dissidents and activists said they feared they were being muzzled.
item.dc:creator: Chang Che and Paul Mozur
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: Bao Pu, a veteran human rights activist, said he feared that Twitter was “putting a limit on the influence” that he could have.

item.title: China Tries to Depict Furor Over Spy Balloon as Sign of U.S. Decline
item.description: Ignoring charges of spying, Beijing says Washington’s “overreaction” is a symptom of the country’s broken politics.
item.dc:creator: David Pierson
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden meeting with Xi Jinping, China’s top leader, in Bali, Indonesia, in November.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: Protests over proposed judicial changes in Israel.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Ilan Rosenberg/Reuters

item.title: Secretive Network Rescues Russia’s Antiwar Dissidents in Nick of Time
item.description: Hundreds of people facing long prison sentences are being spirited out of the country by groups that arrange daring escapes, with one trip using six different cars over more than 4,000 miles.
item.dc:creator: Neil MacFarquhar and Alina Lobzina
item.media:credit: Andrej Vasilenko for The New York Times
item.media:description: Oleg Zavyalov reunited with his sister-in-law and brother after they separately fled Russia.

item.title: A Surprise Pick to Lead the Bank of Japan Faces a Wrenching Choice
item.description: Kazuo Ueda is set to replace the longtime governor who helped put the country on an unorthodox monetary path. Will he change course?
item.dc:creator: Ben Dooley and Hisako Ueno
item.media:credit: Akio Kon/Bloomberg
item.media:description: Kazuo Ueda in 2017. If Parliament approves his nomination, he will be the first academic in the postwar period to lead the Bank of Japan.

item.title: U.S.-China Tensions Rise Over Spy Programs Amid UFO Investigations
item.description: The Biden administration is looking into mysterious U.F.O. encounters and pushing back against China over accusations of widespread espionage.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong, David E. Sanger, Julian E. Barnes and Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Randall Hill/Reuters
item.media:description: A Chinese spy balloon was struck down by a missile from an F-22 fighter jet over the Atlantic Ocean last week.

item.title: As Russia Closes In on Bakhmut, Ukraine Bars Aid Workers From the City
item.description: With Moscow’s forces closing in, the besieged city is too dangerous for the volunteers, Ukrainian commanders said, in what could be a prelude to a Ukrainian withdrawal.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: Libkos/Associated Press
item.media:description: A Ukrainian soldier in Bakhmut on Sunday. After leveling much of the city, the Russians now appear to have surrounded it on three sides.

item.title: Little International Earthquake Aid Has Come to Hard-Hit Corner of Syria
item.description: Since a disastrous earthquake a week ago, little international aid has come to the hard-hit northwest of Syria, which is under the control of opposition forces.
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim and Emily Garthwaite
item.media:credit: Emily Garthwaite for The New York Times

item.title: Assad Agrees to 2 More Border Crossings Into Syria for Earthquake Aid
item.description: The decision is the first time that President Bashar al-Assad has agreed to the cross-border delivery of humanitarian aid to opposition-held territory since the civil war began.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:credit: Emily Garthwaite for The New York Times
item.media:description: Residents and members of the White Helmets worked to clear earthquake rubble in Atarib, Syria, on Sunday.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing: Balloon Tensions Escalate
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:credit: Randall Hill/Reuters
item.media:description: A jet flies by a suspected Chinese spy balloon as it floats off the coast in Surfside Beach, S.C., Feb. 4.

item.title: Ukrainians Demonstrate Training on Leopard Tanks in Poland
item.description: Kyiv’s troops are getting a crash course in using the German-made tanks, less than three weeks after Berlin agreed, under pressure from Poland and others, to let them go to Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes
item.media:credit: Maciek Nabrdalik for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Leopard 2 tank being operated by Ukrainian soldiers at a military base in Swietoszow, Poland, on Monday.

item.title: Upscale Tower That Fell During Turkey Earthquake May Have Had a Design Flaw
item.description: Some structures promoted as being built to modern seismic codes did not withstand the quake in Turkey. One upscale tower that fell may have had a design flaw, engineers said.
item.dc:creator: James Glanz and Ceylan Yeginsu

item.title: Thousands Protest in Israel Over Netanyahu’s Judicial Overhaul
item.description: As Benjamin Netanyahu’s government pressed ahead with plans to limit judicial influence, Israelis thronged to unusually large rallies.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley and Isabel Kershner
item.media:credit: Avishag Shaar-Yashuv for The New York Times
item.media:description: The demonstrations in Jerusalem and elsewhere on Monday followed a speech by Israel’s president in which he warned that the country was “on the brink of constitutional and social collapse.”

item.title: Week After Turkey-Syria Earthquake, Relief Efforts Are Stymied
item.description: A week after a powerful quake struck Turkey and Syria, the combined death toll surpassed 35,000. With more than a million homeless in Turkey alone, there is a desperate need for temporary housing.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard, Gulsin Harman, Hwaida Saad and Jenny Gross
item.category: International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: A camp for displaced earthquake victims in Osmaniye, Turkey, on Sunday.

item.title: Panel Finds Decades of Abuse in Catholic Church in Portugal
item.description: More than 500 people have come forward to say they were abused by representatives of the church, and a new report says the number of victims may surpass 4,800.
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.media:credit: Armando Franca/Associated Press
item.media:description: A Roman Catholic church in Lisbon on Friday. Portuguese bishops established a panel a year ago to look into allegations of abuse.

item.title: The Next Phase in Ukraine
item.description: The war in Ukraine is entering a new phase. We explain each side’s strategy.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Pavlo, a Ukrainian soldier wounded in the eye by a rocket-propelled grenade.

item.title: Russia tightens a claw around Bakhmut, as Wagner fighters claim another village.
item.dc:creator: Shashank Bengali
item.media:credit: Libkos/Associated Press
item.media:description: A Ukrainian soldier in Bakhmut, Ukraine, on Sunday.

item.title: China Says U.S. Balloons Entered Its Airspace Over 10 Times Since 2022
item.description: The claim followed a weekend of aerial theatrics, with Washington and Beijing spotting unidentified flying objects in their airspaces.
item.dc:creator: Daisuke Wakabayashi and Claire Fu
item.media:credit: Randall Hill/Reuters
item.media:description: A U.S. fighter jet shot down the Chinese balloon off the coast of South Carolina on Feb. 4.

item.title: China’s Top Airship Scientist Promoted Program to Watch the World From Above
item.description: Corporate records and media reports reveal an airship scientist at the center of China’s high-altitude balloon program. Companies he has founded were among those targeted by Washington.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley
item.media:credit: Larry Mayer/The Billings Gazette, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A high-altitude balloon floating over Billings, Mont., earlier this month. It was later shot down off the coast of South Carolina.

item.title: How Teens Recovered From the ‘TikTok Tics’
item.description: A wave of teenagers who developed tics during the pandemic has receded, illustrating the powerful influence of stress on the body and the resilience of adolescents.
item.dc:creator: Azeen Ghorayshi and Amber Bracken
item.media:description: Aidan, 18, developed involuntary tics after watching videos on TikTok posted by teenagers claiming to have Tourette’s syndrome. “It looked like Aidan was going crazy,” recalled their mother, Rhonda.

item.title: Russian Prisoners of War in Ukraine Recount ‘Gigantic’ Losses
item.description: Poorly trained Russian soldiers captured by Ukraine describe being used as cannon fodder by commanders throwing waves of bodies into an assault.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: A warden kept watch this month over prisoners of war at a camp in western Ukraine.
